We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and family history suggest an increased risk for colorectal cancer. The recommended screening guidelines for patients with an increased risk due to family history suggest a colonoscopy by age 32 and repeated every 1-2 years thereafter. All other options are either too late for screening or recommend a less effective screening method (flexible sigmoidoscopy).

We refer to the American Cancer Society guidelines for screening and surveillance for colorectal cancer. This patient has multiple risk factors including a family history of colon cancer and iron deficiency anemia. The barium enema findings suggest a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis and the patient’s symptoms are also suggestive of this diagnosis. Given these factors, the current recommendation would be to start colonoscopy screening at age 32 and repeat every 1-2 years thereafter. Option B is incorrect as it is the general guideline for average-risk individuals starting at age 50. Options C and D are not recommended for this patient based on her risk factors and symptoms.

Therefore, she should have earlier and more frequent colonoscopy screenings than the general population. Option (A), colonoscopy by age 32 and repeated every 1-2 years thereafter, is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient. Option (B) is the standard recommendation for average-risk individuals. Option (C) is not frequent enough, given the patient's symptoms and risk factors. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and a family history of colon cancer, which makes her at increased risk for the disease. The recommended screening guidelines for individuals with high risk, such as this patient, are to begin colonoscopy at an earlier age and to repeat it more frequently than for average risk individuals. Option A is the most appropriate screening recommendation for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and family history are concerning for inflammatory bowel disease and/or colon cancer. The recommended screening guidelines for individuals with a first-degree relative with colon cancer before age 60 is colonoscopy starting at age 10 years younger than the age their relative was diagnosed or age 40, whichever is younger. Therefore, this patient should have a colonoscopy by age 32 and repeated every 1-2 years thereafter. Option B is the recommended screening guideline for average-risk individuals starting at age 50. Flexible sigmoidoscopy is not sufficient given the patient’s symptoms and family history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient’s symptoms, history, physical examination, and barium enema findings, the most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis. Since the patient has a family history of colon cancer, screening guidelines suggest that she should begin colonoscopy at an earlier age of 32 and repeated every 1-2 years instead of the recommended age of 50. Therefore, the correct answer is (A).

The patient’s symptoms, family history, and physical examination findings suggest a possible diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease or colorectal cancer. Therefore, the recommended screening guidelines for this patient would be colonoscopy starting at age 32 (10 years before the age at which her family member was diagnosed with colorectal cancer) and repeated every 1-2 years thereafter. Option B is incorrect because the family history and patient’s symptoms warrant earlier and more frequent screening. Option C is incorrect because 3 years between screenings is too long for a patient with these risk factors. Option D is incorrect because sigmoidoscopy only visualizes the left side of the colon and would not be appropriate for this patient’s symptoms and risk factors.
